entry.title: Change_Icons
entry.content:
I am going to teach you how to change a shortcut icon on Windows 11.

Use Icon Editor to Build Icon Library

  1. First of all, you will need to download Greenfish Icon Editor Pro. This editor is totally free and open-source!
  2. By the time downloading, you may head to browser and search for ‚Äúico download‚Äù. Download the .ico files you want.
  3. Follow the setup instructions, install and lauch the icon editor.
    1. At the startup screen, click on New library.
    2. Click on Add resources and choose the .ico you just downloaded.
    3. Click Save as, type the file name and save your file at somewhere permanent.
    4. A window will pop up asking you to select ICL format. Choose PE (32-bit Windows executable). Note: NE format is outdated and not recommended.

Change Icons

  1. Go to the shortcut for which you want to change the icon.
  2. Right click the shortcut and select Properties -> Change Icon -> Browse.
  3. Select your .icl file at the location you just stored.
  4. Select the icon by double clicking it in the icon bar and Click Apply -> OK.

üéâ Congrats! You‚Äôre all done. Enjoy your new icon!

entry.content: Hey everyone! Welcome to my first blog post. I‚Äôll be sharing what I learn and the projects I work on ‚Äî both as a way to document my journey and (hopefully) help others understand some concepts along the way.

entry.title: Linked_List
entry.content:
Data elements are represented by nodes, which are connected using links or pointers.

  • Each element points to only the next element.

  • Each element contains data and a pointer to the next node.

  • Only the head is stored externally from the linked list.

  • Memory is dynamically allocated.

  • Unlike arrays, random access is not possible; traversal must start from the head node, step by step.

  • It doesn‚Äôt waste memory space because nodes are created one by one as needed, allowing the list to grow and shrink dynamically at runtime.

Basic Operations

  • Insert - insert between two elements or insert at the head or end
  • Delete - delete an element
  • Search - search an element using given key
  • Display - display the complete list

    It‚Äôs very important to understand how pointers behave during insertion and deletion ‚Äî you‚Äôll need to figure that out on your own!

Types of Linked List

  1. Singly Linked List
  2. Doubly Linked List
  3. Circular Linked List
  4. Doubly Circular Linked List
  5. Header Linked List

Advanced Operations

  • Concatenate
    • Linked List
    • Circular Linked List
  • Invert
    • Linked List
    • Circular Linked List

‚ùåLast node not detected in this example.

Fixed:

All in One Linked List Code (by Gemini)

Outputs:
Initial list:
NULL
\\
Inserting 10 at the end.
10 -> NULL
Inserting 20 at the end.
10 -> 20 -> NULL
Inserting 5 at the beginning.
5 -> 10 -> 20 -> NULL
Inserting 15 after node with value 10.
5 -> 10 -> 15 -> 20 -> NULL
\\
Searching for node with value 15‚Ä¶
Found node with value: 15
Searching for node with value 99‚Ä¶
Node with value 99 not found.
\\
Current list before deletions:
5 -> 10 -> 15 -> 20 -> NULL
Deleting node with value 10 (middle node).
5 -> 15 -> 20 -> NULL
Deleting node with value 5 (head node).
15 -> 20 -> NULL
Deleting node with value 20 (tail node).
15 -> NULL
Trying to delete a non-existent node (value 100).
15 -> NULL
\\
Freeing the entire list‚Ä¶
List after freeing:
NULL

Process finished with exit code 0

entry.title: Structure
entry.content:
Structure

link different data form together (int, float, char‚Ä¶)

it is a user-defined composite data type

  • Using Initializer Lists (at declaration):¬†Similar to arrays. Values must be in the order members are defined.

  • Using Designated Initializers (C99+):¬†More readable, less error-prone if the struct definition changes. Order doesn‚Äôt matter.

Structs and Pointers (Very Important!)

  • Declaring Pointers to Structs:¬†struct *;

  • Assigning Address:¬†Use the¬†&¬†operator.

  • Accessing Members via Pointers - The Arrow Operator (->):¬†This is the standard, preferred way.

    • Syntax:¬†->

    • Purpose:¬†It dereferences the pointer¬†and¬†accesses the member in one step. It‚Äôs shorthand for¬†(*pointer_name).member_name.

    • Example:

  • Accessing via Pointers - Dereference and Dot ((*).):¬†Less common, more verbose, but shows the underlying mechanism.

  • Dynamic Allocation:¬†Structs are frequently used with¬†malloc¬†to create data on the heap (e.g., linked lists, trees). Remember¬†free!

There are a few more ways to define and use struct in C, and it‚Äôs super useful to know the different styles. Here‚Äôs a rundown of the main syntaxes you‚Äôll see:

Structs and Functions

  • Passing by Value:¬†A¬†copy¬†of the entire struct is passed. Changes inside the function don‚Äôt affect the original. Can be inefficient for large structs.

  • Passing by Pointer (Address):¬†Pass the address (&) of the struct. More efficient (only an address is copied). Allows the function to modify the original struct using the arrow (->) operator. This is the¬†most common¬†way.

  • Returning Structs:¬†Functions can return struct variables (usually by value, so a copy is returned).

üîπ 1. Classic struct, no typedef

‚úîÔ∏è Simple and clear, but a bit wordy.

üîπ 2. Typedef with struct tag

‚úîÔ∏è Very common in real-world code. Clean and flexible.

üîπ 3. Typedef without struct tag

  • Now you can only use Node, there‚Äôs no struct node type name.
  • Can‚Äôt refer to struct node anymore‚Äîjust Node.

‚úîÔ∏è Cleanest if you don‚Äôt need to reference the tag (struct node) anywhere else.

üîπ 4. Anonymous struct with variable

  • No type name, no typedef.
  • Just defines variables a and b directly.

üö´ Not reusable for other variables unless redefined.

üîπ 5. Define and declare at once

‚úîÔ∏è Defines struct and declares variables in one shot.

üîπ 6. Forward declaration (for self-referencing)

‚úîÔ∏è Used when you need to refer to the same struct type inside itself (like for linked lists or trees).

üîö Summary Table:

StyleReusable TypeCleaner SyntaxSelf-Reference
struct node {}‚úÖ Yes‚ùå No‚úÖ Yes
typedef struct node {} Node;‚úÖ Yes‚úÖ Yes‚úÖ Yes
typedef struct {}‚úÖ Yes‚úÖ Yes‚ùå No name to refer to
struct {} with variables‚ùå No‚úÖ Quick‚ùå No

entry.title: Pointer
entry.content:
Normal Variables (Value Variables):

  • Store their data value directly in the memory location allocated to the variable
  • When you access the variable, you directly access its value

Pointer Variables:

  • Store memory addresses as their values
  • Provide indirect access to data by storing the location (address) where the actual data is stored
  • Can be dereferenced to access or modify the value at the stored address

Reference:

  • In the context of pointers, a ‚Äúreference‚Äù is essentially the memory address that points to where data is stored
  • When we say a pointer ‚Äúreferences‚Äù something, it means the pointer contains the memory address of that data
  • For example, if we have a pointer p that points to variable x, we say ‚Äúp references x‚Äù or ‚Äúp holds a reference to x‚Äù

Dereferencing:

  • ‚ÄúDereferencing‚Äù is the act of accessing or modifying the value stored at the memory address contained in a pointer
  • It means ‚Äúfollow this address to get to the actual data‚Äù

I know these notes are pretty dense and were mostly written for my own benefit. I‚Äôd be impressed if anyone besides me makes it to the end.

entry.title: Time_Complexity
entry.content:
Algorithm

  • Input ‚Äì Takes zero or more inputs.
  • Output ‚Äì Produces at least one output.
  • Definiteness ‚Äì Each step is clearly and unambiguously defined.
  • Finiteness ‚Äì The algorithm must end after a finite number of steps.
  • Effectiveness ‚Äì Each step can be carried out exactly and in a finite amount of time.

Pseudocode

Flow Chart

Time Complexity

The cost of time while executing an algorithm.

evaluate by the number of executions

comments, bracket, and funciton & variable declaration don‚Äôt count

initialization of variable while declaring count

function call count

indicate as T(n)

BIG-O : Worst-Case analysis

f(n ) ‚â§ c ‚ãÖ g(n)

Œò     : Average-Case analysis

c1 ‚ãÖ g(n) ‚â§ f(n) ‚â§ c2 ‚ãÖ g(n)

Œ©     : Best-Case analysis

f(n) ‚â• c ‚ãÖ g(n)

Space Complexity

S(P) = C + SP(I)

C : Fixed Space Requirement (Constant)

SP(I) : Variable Space Requirement (Variable)

There is no structure variable and recusive call, so SP(I) = 0.

addition function has 4 references and a return value, declaration of int takes 4 bytes. Therefore, fixed space requires CS (4+1) * 4 bytes = 20 bytes

addition function does not contain dynamic allocate memory. SP = 0 byte

S(P) = CS + SP(I) = 20 + 0 = 20 bytes

SP(I):

no stack space cost (no recursive call)

possess structure variable (analyze if it is called by value):

4*n - if list[ ] is called by value (determine by main function‚Äôs array length)

0 or C - if list[ ] is called by address (main function only pass head address)

We assumed int takes 4 bytes, float takes 4 bytes, address takes 2 bytes and list[ ] is called by address .

SP (I) : possess structure variable, but it is not called by value.

there is stack space cost (recursive call)

stack spaces for each recursive call:

SP(I)=list head address + n + return address = 2 + 4 + 2=8

n times recursive calls SP(I) = 8n bytes

entry.title: Array
entry.content:
Array

In C it is a fixed-size, ordered, and homogeneous sert.

Search of an array starts with 0.

If an array is declared without initialization, the elements will contain garbage values whatever that found in the memory.

Anything may happen if you try to access to index out of range.

Arrays store values contiguously in the memory.

  • Traversal - This operation is used to print the elements of the array.
  • Insertion - It is used to add an element at a particular index.
  • Deletion - It is used to delete an element from a particular index.
  • Search - It is used to search an element using the given index or by the value.
  • Update - It updates an element at a particular index.

Cons of Arrays in C

No push/pop/insert/delete ‚Äî you do everything manually.

You can‚Äôt store mixed data types like in Python lists.

Accessing arr[9999] won‚Äôt throw an error ‚Äî it‚Äôll just break stuff silently (undefined behavior).

When NOT to Use Arrays

When Frequent insert/delelte is required.

Alternative : Use linked list, dynamic array, or queue

You don‚Äôt know the number of elements in advance.

Alternative : Use malloc + realloc, or linked structures

You want to store mixed types.

Alternative : Use struct

entry.title: Recursion
entry.content:
Non-recursive methods (while, repeat until‚Ä¶) are often more efficient.
Recursion involves additional overhead and can consume more memory due to the call stack (e.g., push and pop operations).

Recursion Examples:
Factorial, Fibonacci Number, G.C.D., Binomial Coefficient, Ackermann‚Äôs Funciton, Tower of Hanoi, Permutation

Base Case: The condition that ends the recursion.
General Case: The function that makes the next recursive call.

Tower of Hanoi:


You can figure the following code out easily by considering case: n=3.
